importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, a significant development in national space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from August to December 2025 encompasses the launch, calibration, and eventual full operational use of the H1 satellite, reflecting the timeline for the satellite's deployment and integration into national applications.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space program.
The H1 satellite was launched by Pakistan's space agency SUPARCO from China's Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle chemical and material changes on Earth, useful for agriculture, water resource monitoring, disaster response, and environmental assessment.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, urban planning, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.

The launch is seen as a strategic advancement in Pakistan’s space capabilities and a reflection of its partnership with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
The H1 satellite is part of a broader push by Pakistan to expand its space program, which has already sent three satellites into orbit this year (H1, EO-1, and KS-1).
It may take approximately two months to calibrate the H1 satellite’s systems before it becomes fully operational.
SUPARCO Chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan stated that the data from H1 will revolutionize agricultural productivity, climate resilience, and natural resource management.
The launch underscores the growing strategic and technological partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure project linking Xinjiang, China, with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite's capabilities in geohazard monitoring are expected to support CPEC development by improving risk assessment and infrastructure planning.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key spokesperson for SUPARCO, providing official statements on the strategic significance of the H1 satellite and its national impact.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite supports precision agriculture by detecting crop health and soil conditions, improving food security.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral data helps detect early signs of natural disasters such as landslides or floods, improving national disaster preparedness.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The data from H1 can assist in making informed decisions in urban development, especially in rapidly growing areas.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite helps monitor water quality and distribution, essential for sustainable development in arid regions like Pakistan.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, via SUPARCO from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025. The satellite, equipped with hyperspectral imaging technology, enables detailed Earth observation for precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster management, and urban planning. The launch marks a major advancement in Pakistan’s space program and strengthens its strategic cooperation with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While the satellite will take about two months to calibrate before full operation, it is expected to significantly enhance national capabilities in managing natural resources, improving agricultural productivity, and detecting geohazard risks. This milestone is part of Pakistan’s broader push to expand its space capabilities, which includes the successful deployment of two other operational satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, in 2025.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
